course.subject: ENGG
course.name: First Year Cornerstone Engineering Design Project Course
course.description: This project course is designed specifically for first year engineering students. This course aims at providing engineering students experiential learning experience through exposing students to knowledge and skills from different SENG disciplines before making decision on their majors. Students in this course will be divided into design teams. Each team will use the acquired knowledge and skills to design and build an engineering artifact, e.g. an airship. In order to offer the course at scale, the technical components will be offered online and students would be engaged in experiential learning through working on team projects. For First year Engineering students only.

reviews.author: qjk
reviews.title: Terrible Course especially with Online Teaching
reviews.comment_content:
Build a remote controlled car out with Arduino.

Sounds easy, but here's the deal: the equipment they give you is absolutely trash.

So, you built your car. It's made out of lightweight material and has an aerodynamic shape. You start up your remote control app and tell your car to move. It moves forward about 1 meter. Oops! It shuts down, because the board has overheated. So, you wait a few minutes for it to cool down, and you start it up again. It runs for a few seconds. Oops! It shuts down again, this time because you set the power too high and the current is too much. So, you load up your program and turn down the motor power setting. You start up the car again. Oops! Your battery has run out. You decide to make a rope and hang yourself.
reviews.comment_teaching: Online teaching this semester. It's hard to describe your problems to the TA over Zoom and it's hard for them to figure out your problem, so lessons are pretty much useless and you have to figure out your problems yourself.
reviews.comment_grading: There are some online modules which require you to study some materials and do some MC questions. Also they have a weekly "build log" where you take photos of your car and write some stuff about it, sort of like a diary. Every minor assignment counts towards the final grade, each counts for a few percent. Even if you can't make a functional car you can still get about 70% of the marks because of the assignments. You need to make videos of your car which counts for about 20% of the grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Terrible. Don't apply this course if you don't want to end up killing yourself. Prepare to spend days working on your car. One moment it's working and the next it's not. Be prepared for suicidal thoughts.

reviews.comment_grading:
Individual (30%) work:
HKMOOC - 5%
Launch Level Demo - 10%
Robot Design - 5%
Kicking Mechanism Design Sketch - 5%
Attendance for Build Sessions - 5%

Team (70%) work:
First Build Demo - 15%
Final Competition Part 1 (Dribble/Shoot) - 20%
Final Competition Part 2 (Football Match) - 25%
Team Logo/Uniform - 10%

Upon first glance, the grading may seem quite fair for a project course. HOWEVER, the biggest problem is that any idiot with more than 2 braincells will be able to 100% the individual section. Furthermore, any team with more than 4 collective braincells will be able to 100% everything EXCEPT the final competition. The STAs (who grade you) are trying to be nice and generous, but that leads to everything - almost your entire grade - coming down to one lesson, and in our case, a final football match and competition we only did well in thanks to luck. For context, our robots were basically trashcans with wheels, with cardboard torn up and taped onto them, and only won because we cheesed our 'kicking mechanism' to be sticks coming out of the robot (they didn't even move).

(Also, not to mention, initially, part 1 of the final competition had all 3 of your robots placed on a table styled like a football pitch and they had to pass and dribble through a specified path to score a goal. Initially, there were lots of sharp turns and corners but since it was too hard, they made it a straight line LMAO so everyone aced it.)

Essentially, your final grade was determined by how you did in the final football match, which was... essentially luck. Your teammates control the robots, but that doesn't mean anything. Our team literally just got lucky - maybe the other team robots didn't work, or the ball hit at the wrong angle, etc etc...

Overall, I'm pretty sure I got 100% in everything, but coming 2nd place in the final competition gave our team an A. I am very happy, but I do not imagine the same can be said for everyone.
reviews.comment_workload:
The work you do, and the effort you put in, does not mean you will get a good grade. Unfortunately, that will most likely always be the case in such a competitive course, especially true for us since we had a football match. Teams that had super cool kicking mechanisms, using clever ways to implement things like actuators, motors and whatnot, 3d printing parts to join it all together, only to come last??

I, and some others, spent several nights, especially leading up to the build demo and final competition working in the lab until up to 4am. The lab is usually open at this time, which saved many teams.

Also, despite having a team of 5, I am giving you a 100% guarantee that we could have done just as well, if not better, with just 3. Some team members did absolutely nothing, partially because there WAS nothing to do... We split the robot building into coding, 3d design and electronics, and they didn't really do anything so... ??? I hope you're a hard worker and don't piggyback your team if you do take this course.

reviews.title: Not worth 3 credits.
reviews.comment_content:
This is a debut course (though "tested" before in winter terms) aimed toward first-year SENG inductees who would like to have a multi-faceted experience of engineering and design prior to declaring a major.

The course will cover topics in the fields of mechanical, electronics and computer engineering, and the final project consists of working with a group to build an airship with an Arduino microprocessor, controlled via Bluetooth using an Android device.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Most of the technical information will be taught through a "flipped classroom", and the completion of which will constitute a part of your grade. The online course will go through the necessary information you will need to construct your airship.

However, the information provided is too specific and rarely useful apart from its model use. This means it is difficult to solve problems on known information, as the arising problems are likely to be beyond the scope of the online course. Problem-solving must thus be accomplished outside of what the instructors provide and has already lost many groups valuable time due to the large student/instructor ratio as well as a lack of competent TAs, who are more likely to be screwing around than actually providing useful solutions.

reviews.comment_workload:
If you foresee yourself having even one extra-curricular commitment that might hinder your ability to work with your group during the off-hours of the week, it is best for you to AVOID this class. In fact, this goes for all project classes in general.

You are guaranteed 3 hours a week to work with your team, but it is certain that you will need to spend much more time with your group to solve the plethora of unforeseen problems that will arise. Since UST students' schedules are usually unique, it will mean that you must work during the off-hours to accomplish anything outside of the 3-hour time slot during class.

reviews.author: P-Dawg
reviews.title: Heavy workload with debatable payoff
reviews.comment_content:
For this semester, our final objective was to build a total of 4 soccer robots (1 for backup), each equipped with a shooting mechanism used to handle a mini soccer ball, and compete against other groups in a soccer match.

In the first 4 weeks, we were to learn a bit of lab safety, the basics of electronics (content resembling ELEC1100 but way less in depth), basic programming in C++ for Arduino, and writing apps with Appinventor. This is done by yourself through a website HKMOOC, in which your performance is counted towards your final grade. A "first build demo" is then conducted, in which you demonstrate what you learnt by making an app to control 2 motors via bluetooth communication. Despite being challenging in nature, model answers have been provided by STAs (Student Technical Advisors).

Next, you begin your actual construction of your 4 robots for the "final competition". In this period, you are taught how to use 3D printers and the laser cutter, as well as Fusion 360, a 3D modelling application. In this period, you are given freedom to work on the project however you like, and devote however much time you deem necessary. In between, there will be a "launch level demo" (essentially a progress check).

---

[Conclusion] All in all, the grades you get from this course are not proportional at all to the effort you put in, since most of it comes down to the final competition, and there may be unexpected factors there. If you're looking to get a good grade, I do not recommend this course. However, this course was ultimately a break from sitting in lectures, and instead we were putting things into practice and getting our hands dirty. You also learn quite a fair bit from the course, and can benefit in other areas (e.g. access to the lab, friends from the course, etc.)

tl;dr, Echoing the title, the workload is heavy, but most of the payoff doesn't go toward your grades, but to other areas.
reviews.comment_teaching: This part is tricky to comment on, since you do most of the learning on your own. You learn things given to you on HKMOOC, then experiment with the project yourself. When you are looking for help, you are most likely looking for the STAs in charge. Although the STAs are helpful with things you may be stuck on, or using equipment e.g. the laser cutter, you should ultimately be prepared to learn things on your own, whether it'd be catching up to things you don't know, or specific research needed for your robot.

---

The grading is not particularly bad, but not good at all, especially given the amount of time you would have to invest in this project. Freeriders may also affect your progress, possibly denting your final grade even further. In addition, there only are so many winners in the final competition. In other words, not "winning" would most likely knock you down to B range. (Our group was one of those that didn't do well in the final competition, and belonged in the lowest mark category).

Make sure you treat HKMOOC seriously, because not getting full marks there is also going to dent your grade. I didn't get the full 5% thinking that it'd be fine, and my grade may have ended up hurt.

Other than the above 2, I got full marks in the rest. My overall marks were not disclosed. It was a B+.

Is that bad? Not really, if anything it's pretty great. Was it worth the amount of time I put into this project? Also not really.
reviews.comment_workload:
I'm only year 1, but it was the course with the heaviest workload from my experience (I would've wanted to rate this an E, but I probably haven't experienced enough of UST to know). Near the final competition, I practically skipped all my other classes just to come to the lab and work on the project, and so did my teammates. I also stayed overnight in the lab the night before the contest to work on the "robot team uniform".

Do note that we have to construct those robots and their shooting mechanisms from literal scratch. A design has to be thought out, it has to be made and tested. You have to be prepared (both physically and mentally, I mean it) to make iterations and iterations of your work, abandoning things that just didn't work, and making certain sacrifices.

Not to mention that you'd have to account for time spent on learning e.g. the wiring and electronics, and spending extra time if your group has a freerider (which when you have groups of ~6, makes this a pretty likely occurrence).

reviews.author: Edmund Teng
reviews.comment_content:
This is a relatively new course added by the engineering department which aims to promote experiential learning (learning through experience and not lectures). This course aims to teach students to equip themselves with the knowledge required to complete a final project (in this semester, it was to make an off road vehicle that could climb ramps, navigate through an obstacle course and transport water). In this course, students are assessed through a variety of ways:

An online module called HKMOOC (20%) - students do online activities such as watching short videos of professors teaching a concept, then answering questions about the taught materials, which are graded.
A "Proof of Concept" module (10%) - students have to demo their understanding of what they learnt from HKMOOC by doing various individual and team tasks, as set by the course instructors
A "Presenting Ideas" module (25%) - involves presenting orthographic drawings of the design you will want to use for the final project, along with completing a team portfolio
The Project module (35%) - In the later parts of this course (from week 8 onwards, if I recall), students have to complete the project, using all the knowledge that they have learned throughout the course. The project is generally split into 2 builds (both are graded), where students have to build an off road vehicle, along with a trailer, that can be connected to the vehicle automatically. The first build will require students to complete around 3 tasks separately, where the 3 tasks have a direct relationship to the tasks that the students have to be able to complete in the final build. In our case, the 3 tasks were to be able to climb a ramp, navigate in a figure 8, and have a chemical battery (of your own creation) driven trailer drive out of a box. The final build was a combination of all 3 of these tasks, except that they occur seamlessly. First, teams had to make a chemical battery driven trailer go straight for around 2-3 meters, make it attach to the vehicle by controlling the vehicle, then do the rest of the tasks. If I recall, teams were graded by how much water they could transport within 10 minutes, and on how fast their vehicles (without the trailers) were.
reviews.comment_teaching: Most of the teaching involved in this course is in the HKMOOC online module. Other than that, if you require assistance, it would be the course STA's that will help you, and only very rarely do you actually see the professors in person.
reviews.comment_grading: Not quite sure about grading, but I ended up with a B. I got a 91% on the online module, which was a mistake on my part because you could technically do the questions together with your group (each person has 2 tries per question, meaning up to 5 tries per group to guess the answer, and 1 more try per person to key in the correct answer after that). Other than that and the project side of things, I believe I got 100% on everything. For the project, my group completed all the first build requirements, but did quite poorly for the final build due to some mechanical issues. That is all the information I was given regarding the grading, and I have no idea about anything else related to the grading, besides that I got a B.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is minimal, but only if your team works well together. For me, my teammates did close to nothing, so the workload was quite high for me comparatively. But even then, it was definitely manageable. Unfortunately, you don't get to pick your group mates, so if you want to do this course and aim to get A range, it's better to pray for good group mates that will actually do work.

You might have to do all Mechanical (3D printing and woodcutting/lasercutting and structural design), Electronic (wiring) , programming (arduino and mit app inventor) and the worst part Chemical engineering (constructing a motor driving battery from scrap)all by yourself.
Though a good team might ease some burden but its up to luck.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Let's be honest, you can really learn stuff here about practicality and all those bloody trade offs when doing engineering design. But don't expect the  professors to teach you any useful stuff. Just ask the Lab TAs, who are very helpful, and ignore the professors. They are basically useless. BTW, you might want to really pay attention of the programming part of the MOOC and do the MOOC with your teammates to minimise errors.
Kelvin is a nice lab TA. Generally a nice, chill and useful guy.
reviews.comment_grading:
Having consumed most of my time in the semester, I only got a B
IT'S NOT WORTH THE TIME!!!!!
reviews.comment_workload:
Extremely high, especially it you have shxt teammates. I was fortunate enough to have a fairly good programmer but I was still pushed to the very edge.
Think about it, you have to spend your own time buying the materials which is already hard to find and it might not fit the car. You also have to learn solidworks or other cad programme to aid your design by 3D printing. Worse still, you have to really think of a design that can climb without sacrificing speed and stability.

reviews.author: amyriad
reviews.title: Quite depending on the ability of yourself and your groupmates
reviews.comment_content:
The product for the project may be changed in each semester, so it is for reference only.
This semester has the goal of making a truck with Arduino Nano board containing sketch (code) connecting a trailer carrying water being controlled by an Android App compiled using App Inventor passing through the obstables and climbing up and down the oblique surface.

Students have to buy materials outside within a budget of HKD 350 (no other currency allowed (so no Taobao / Amazon), and receipts have to be provided to claim back the money and give the bought materials to them), it is generally not easy to find the thing that you want. (And the default motor they provided have the axis that can fit in a kind of wheels that are not provided so either you have to buy that (if you can find) or have to make an adaptor (usually by 3D printing) to connect your custom wheel to the motor)

The project consists of a self-made vehicle with separated truck and trailer, where the truck is driven by the motor connected to the H-bridge connecting to the Arduino board and it is powered by 2 3.7 V LiPo batteries. (The battery box they provided cannot touch the two sides of the battery so you may need to attach Aluminium foils to it to make it work). The Arduino board receives data from a bluetooth module that is sent from a Android device by a self-made Android App compiled by App Inventor. The trailer is driven by a self-made chemical battery (usually the Aluminium-Carbon battery as the materials are provided (A typical Zn-C battery with Zn replaced by Al only). You can buy your own material to make the battery also if you wish (within the budget))

The truck has to connect to the trailer using mechanical means (no tapes) (usually magnets) (remember that you can only control the truck but not the trailer with chemical battery)

3 motors and 2 servo motors at most (although it seems that nobody use servo motors)

You cannot form your own groups, and the groups is paired up not quite randomly by course instructors. (It is ensured that at least 1 member among the group cannot speak Cantonese / Putonghua so English should be the only common language, (at least) 2 genders in the group, and may consider the strengths of every groupmates in the grouping process that we don't know)

No presentation this semester.
reviews.comment_teaching:
1. The online module:
It covers different area of knowledge which are generally useful to the course (although some are even irrelevant).
Generally it includes most programming basics in Arduino and App Inventor. Also, it provides the information in using the H-bridge. But it is not updated so it may include some knowledge which is for the previous semesters or other similar courses but not even useful for this year's project (e.g. this semester requires us to build a water-carrying truck with a trailer, but the online module contains some questions regarding to the airship like the resistance and turbulence)

2. The Instructors and TAs
The TAs are helpful in providing suggestions to the groups regarding to the design, the program, the method to use the tools, etc, and they are willing to help.

The instructors are supposed to cover the area field they teach at the start of some week's lesson. They may invite some professors to explain different stuffs like chemical battery, engineering basics, Orientation Sensor for App Inventor, etc. They can help much in the design knowledge.
reviews.comment_grading:
1. You know nothing about your scores except the one you submitted like the homework an indivdual / group test build.
2. The grading may not reflect the actual performance much as the final competition contributes a lot.
3. The grading does not reflect how much work you have done but the final performance mainly.
4. The grading may be affected by groupmate performance although each teammate may receive different grades.

Marking scheme attached below.
reviews.comment_workload:
Summary: Very heavy
The course material (online module) is probably the part with the lightest workload as it only requires answering some questions. (within the first few weeks) (although some of the questions are not even relevant to the project)

After that, the indivdual demo checklist is still acceptable as it only requires following the steps provided in the HKMOOC online module.

The heaviest workload part happens after the first third of the whole course, when groups have to start concentrating on the final design. There are already 3 hours of lessons per week (in Fall/Spring, Winter schedule is even intense with 15 hours per week), the total course time is approximately 30 hours plus the online module (~ 6 hours).

Although there may be some groupmates who may not lead the progress, but probably should still need to help in the whole design if they do not want to be considered as freeriders and being rated poorly in the peer assessment. Those who have adequate knowledge in specific area have to complete everything part as it is rare to find more than 1 groupmate with the same ability to distribute the workload. (especially the electronic part, the programming part, 3D design part and the mechanical part, even heavier for those who is the only one who can complete more than 1 of the above parts in the group). (ref: The champion of the final competition this semester is a group with 1 teammates doing most of the stuffs)

Although it is not necessary to work after class, but most teammates prefer doing so. Using the week before the first build demo and the final competition are the time when many people spend more than 10 hours per day in contributing in the design as many things are hard to debug, and many problems are hard to spot out and solve, and the course material doesn't help much in this. Therefore the workload is so heavy that you are not supposed to have time to sleep, eating dinner, socialize and instead have to stay up night. (These two weeks are close to mid-term and final also)

Also the team is supposed to sumbit a team profolio which requires answering questions after all.

reviews.author: JJThompson
reviews.title: Tough course for Coding/Electronic beginners
reviews.comment_content:
The course focus on 3 domains: Mechanical, Electronics and Android App development (App Inventor only)
The course starts late at around 2-3 weeks after semester commences, and the first 2 lessons are just for introduction and team building. You will be assigned to form a team of 4-5 students with paired TA. Then you will need to complete the HKMOOC online learning module. After that, you will need to design a prototype by CAD drawing or simply draw by paper-and-pencil and the instructors will come and say 'it won't work' which you usually ignore them xd. The remaining part of the course is building your airship and keep doing programming debuting and App improvement for better control. There will be a team portfolio to be submitted before the competition. At the final competition you will need to control your own airship (all team members must control in different tasks) AND other teams' airship to fight for your performance and extra grade marks. There will be a 1% upgrade task in the competition that may help, where speed, stability and ease of control will be crucial to your success.

It will be really challenging for ones without programming or electronic backgrounds as the covered knowledge are new to you and they are like rushing towards your brain in the online modules. If you are beginners, pray for getting into a team with  teammates capable of carrying you through. Recommend to all students with basic Arduino programming exposure. As for Android app development it's rather easy, where the course teaches you to use AppInventor for that which is way easier than programming.

You should work with your teammates cohesively and arrange time to build the airship. (My team always appear in the lab ha)
reviews.comment_teaching: The online module is all of the teachings, and they are somehow not very useful to your final build. The instructors are quite passive in terms of teaching. The TAs are sometimes helpful, but overall I think you will be on your own. Sam(one of the instructors) is very helpful yet, you can ask him anything related to programming or app.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is nice, as a B should be guaranteed as long as you participate in every part of the module and don't piss off some of the instructors ha.

20%~Online modules(HKMOOC)
10%~2 Live Demos
25%~Design Drawings&Team Portfolio
35%~Final Build Demo&Competition

Grades are quite unknown as canvas don't show. Our team got 4th over 8 teams in the end,   
but as we work very hard in building the airship and got full in all the Demos, we manage to get As.(all team members should receive same gradings unless there are free riders.)
reviews.comment_workload: The course should be giving credits depending on how hardworking the students are and how eager they are to design and make things perfect. The workload depends on whether you want to build an excellent model, and if so then you will be spending a lot of time in the app trying to make all those improvements. If not, then you should at least contribute in the team, which it's still quite time consuming. Prepare for at least 3 hours in the build sessions. (My team is always in the lab as mentioned xd.)

reviews.author: Sam ng
reviews.title: Good if you have great groupmates
reviews.comment_content: The goal is to build up an airship and corresponding components like electronic kits. There is a competition at the end. l think it doesn't matter a lot for the grade because l am quite sure that our team get 6 or 7th rank last but l still get A-
reviews.comment_teaching: You need to learn all the stuff on the internet. There are some STAs in lab to give some advice if you encounter any problem with the project.
reviews.comment_grading: If your airship can fly and be controlled properly, you will get a fine grade. I get A- even we get around 6,7th rank in the competition.
reviews.comment_workload: If you have good groupmates, then you will have very little things to do. They will carry you. If there is no one helpful in your team, you better quit the course or get ready for the extremely-heavy workload

reviews.author: 正義必得伸長
reviews.comment_content: Students are divided into design groups of five people and the team stays the same for the whole semester. The students work together to build an airship with arduino boards, motors, balloons, and some resources that can be purchased through stores. Its core value is team work, so it is quite challenging and provides valuable experience as for working with others.

The solid knowledge as for electronics, dynamics, and MIT controlling app are mostly taught through HKMOOC, the 20 percent in online activities is based on the performance on answering the questions on the mooc, some of them can be ambiguous, not so directly taught, or hard to figure out and might spends quite a lot of time if you want to get good grade.

reviews.author: anoynymousse
reviews.title: Great concept with lackluster performance
reviews.comment_content:
The content taught is quite interesting. The course is all about building an airship from scratch, learning the fundamentals of Mechanical Engineering, Computer Engineering, Electrical Engineering along the way. You will be required to solder an Arduino with a breakout board, batteries, and propellers together( warning: these equipment provided are quite fragile and need a lot of repeatedly precise soldering because they break down frequently).
Create an airship that can be controlled by an app by MIT appInventor. The knowledge applied is usually out of the content, so be ready to ask alot of questions!
reviews.comment_teaching:
To be fair, the instructors are quite good and knowledgeable about their craft. They can be quite helpful as well if you know what questions to ask. TAs on the other hand are clumsy and just fucking around with little to no knowledge about the course.( no offense)

There are only in class lectures for the first 3 weeks, then teaching is done through an online platform (HKMOOC) which is pretty okay( i had prior knowledge on the content).

Most of the learning is through experience, failures and self help. Good teammates are crucial because a lot of times the content is not sufficient and you need to search for extra knowledge yourself.
reviews.comment_grading: Got a C for all my efforts which doesn't make sense. Should be graded for efforts not the end product because there are so many variables. Look for grading scheme in previous reviews.
reviews.comment_workload:
This is the most shitty workload course I ever took. Even it is a 3 credit course, you probably end up spending 10++ hours every week in the lab trying to fix your not-working-but-seems-fine airship. Even before the airship building starts, HKMOOC gives you a huge surprise by the humongous workload by cramming a whole course about Arduino or AppInventor into one week and expects you to score good grades and meet the deadline.
This is a course that makes you either skip your other courses and extra curricular activities to commit. If you want to commit to other stuff, please do not take this course.
Pray hard to get good teammates or just quit before the add-drop period. Don't let toxic people ruin your day and fuck up your grades.
I had prior knowledge but shitty teammates were just pulling my leg. Try to encourage teammates to self learn if you don't want to become Einstein by the end of the course but get a shit grade.

reviews.author: chw
reviews.comment_content: The content is interesting. They teach you what are the factors that will affect an airship and ask you to build your own airship. Each team of four to five people would build an airship in a semester.
reviews.comment_teaching: The HKMOOC is very bad. It is difficult to understand what they are talking about if you have not studied that part before. However, the support from the lab is very good. You can access the lab and ask for help almost any time.
reviews.comment_grading: As long as your airship can fly, the grade would not bad.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is extremely high. The time you spend on this course is greater than other courses a lot. You need to build an airship with three hours a week. That is not possible unless all of your members are doing quite well. You would need to spend extra time on it. Finding your members during the holiday to buy some materials. reviews.author: xniac1998
reviews.comment_content: You can have access to all the tools and material in the lab, and try to use interesting stuff such as 3D-printing. For those geeks and who are gonna to major in hardware and machnic the things tought in the class is useful, undoubtedly.

reviews.author: Orange_C
reviews.title: A very Demanding course requiring a lot of self study and team work
reviews.comment_content:
Its all about making an airship.
First you will learn about some basic knowledge on electronics, mechanics and computer programming. Then you will be required to use these knowledge to solve some problems. And after this you will be designing and finally making the airship with your teammate. The whole design is good, since they want you to apply what you learn to the airship. But there are some problems, which I will talk about in the teaching part.
reviews.comment_teaching:
They want us to learn in a new mode. This is fine. But the materials they provided is not really relevant to what we are doing. Sometimes it is too general and sometimes it is too specific. When you are completing your work, you still need to Google for other information or you won't be able to finish it. The TAs are helpful but most of the time they are not knowledgeable enough to solve all the problems.
And the professors rarely show up in class, even if they do, they will basically just provide "inspiration", instead of concrete knowledge. I think some lectures are still needed.
reviews.comment_grading: I think the grading is good because all members in the group get A range. There is a syllabus but you don't really know how many points you get for each part. Just follow the timeline will guarantee you an A range, I think.
reviews.comment_workload: In the first part of the lecture, all you need to do is to watch some online videos and finish some online quizzes following the video. It is not a lot but if you try to deadline fighter, it will take 3-4 hours and ruin your Friday.(Quizzes are due every Friday night). After this you need to figure out how to programme the Arduino and get the correct way of attaching wires to different components. The lack of relevant knowledge may make this process quite time consuming and sometimes frustrating. Finally you need to spend time on building the airship, shoot a video and make a poster. The time needed varies from group to group, but the average is around 3-4 hours per week(class time excluded).

reviews.author: _shing_
reviews.title: Hard work but worth it
reviews.comment_content:
For this course, we had to build a total of 4 soccer robot. 3 main robot + 1 spare (optional). At the end of the course, we would need to play against other teams. The higher the ranking and goal difference we had, the better the grade. Apart from the final competition, we also had to complete a series of task with robot. Such as goalkeeping  and dribbling. We also had to make a case for the robot with a team logo. The logo has to be 3D printed but not the casing.
You get to learn skills such as 3D printing, laser cutting, using fusion 360, using power tools, Arduino coding etc.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching materials were uploaded onto a platform called HKMOOC. We had to review the materials by ourselves and complete some quizzes at the end. However, the videos on the platform was pretty old and weren't that helpful. It would be better if you just asked the course STA or google the things you need. A lot of self-learning needed.
The instructors rarely appeared during the course and they did not  teach much. Chan only appeared during the beginning of the course and at the end of the course. When he came to the course, he would try to encourage us and talk about some general engineering principles.  Apart from that, each team also got a 15 minute consultation session with him. Where he would take a look at our robot and point out some problems that we may have to look out for.
The course STA were extremely helpful and warm. If we encountered any problems, we would ask them for help.
reviews.comment_grading:
25% individual score & 75% team score
HKMOOC Individual 5%
Launch Level Demo Individual 10%
Design Sketch for Kicking Mechanism Individual 5%
Build Session Attendance Individual 5%
Robot Design and Team Role Team 5%
First Build Demo Team 15%
Team Logo & Team Uniform Design Team 10%
Final Competition Task 1 Team 20%
Final Competition Task 2 Team 25%

The difficulty of the final task was changed abruptly and almost every group got full mark. So your grade relies heavily on the final competition and your individual assignment. I got second place in the final competition and scored full mark for the two tasks. For individual assignments, I got full mark except for HKMOOC. I think I got 85-90% on it. I got an A+ for the course.
reviews.comment_workload:
This is course with high workload. Even with a good team, you may need to spend more than 3 hours per week in the lab. If you are unlucky and you need to carry the whole team, you may need to spend most of your free time in the lab building the robot and debugging your code.
If you are only taking 12 credits worth of courses, you might want to consider this as one of the course as this is one of the few course where you can gain hands on experience on building things. The skills you learn such as laser cutting are useful in future projects as well. I would say the time you spend will not go to waste,

reviews.author: KTZ11
reviews.title: Don't pick this course
reviews.comment_content:
In this semester, you would need to build a remote air-propelled car and control it using your phone and Arduino. As the course description suggested, it tries to give learning experience of different SENG disciplines, so you would need to learn things including building an android app, Bluetooth, Arduino programming, some electronics and mechanics of a car. You can also have a try on 3d modeling.

The learning material of this course is mainly delivered through an online platform called HKMOOC.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The instructors teach nearly nothing and want you to learn by self-directed learning and trial and error. The lectures are just useless teamwork activities which are completely unrelated to the car, eg they would ask you to design a way for people to store their mask.

The first half of the course was self-learning on HKMOOC, and you will learn the android app, Arduino and the wiring of the electronic components. This part is fine. The second half of the course is the assembly of the car, and this is the horrible part. They give no guidance on the project and you will need to work everything entirely on your own.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading method:
quizzes on HKMOOC: 20%

Live demos on Android and Arduino: 10%
(you have to show that you can create an Android app and Arduino program to turn the motor in different speed & direction)

First build: 10%
(you have to show that your car can go in a path of figure 8)

Final build: 20%
(a competition among different teams. Team members will have to do separate tasks with their car, like figure 8 and U-turn parking. Grade base on your ranking)

Build log: 5%
(a weekly journal that records what you did to improve the car)

Reflection after final competition: 5%

Final drawing: 5%
(a drawing of the front, side and top view of your car)

Breakout session participation: 5%

Breakout design activities: 15%
( need to discuss features that improve the car, some breakout activity are not related to the car tho)

Team design sketch: 5%
(a sketch of the thing discussed in breakout session)

The final competition really depends on your luck, whether your car functions properly or not.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload of this course is huge. You have to make the car from scratch. And since there is no guidance on how you should improve your car, you have to do the trial and error yourself. There is just so many variables that you have to control, like the size of the car, wheel size & material, the position of the fan, etc. This means you really can't find what is the problem that makes your car not working, and you can easily spend a whole day in the lab and achieves absolutely nothing. Even if you successfully make the car move and turn in one try, it might not work on the next try. You will also encounter random problems frequently like poor wire connection with the motor and parts falling apart. For me, I spend 2 days 10 am - 8 pm in the lab just to finish the first build, and it is super frustrating. Luckily I got teammates who are active and willing to help each other, which makes this process a little bit less painful. I highly suggest meeting with teammates and work in the lab instead of work at home solo. Not only there are more useful tools and material available at the lab(I got a try to use 3d printing, one of the few exciting moments during the course), you can also speed up the whole thing by working with teammates. But overall the workload of this course is still really high, and there is be a lot of pressure and frustration in the process.

reviews.author: ilovecatsss
reviews.title: Weirdo course
reviews.comment_content: So this course basically requires you to build a chem off-roader (which is basically a car controlled by arduino and a tralier powered by a self made battery, holding a cup of water )(and yeah its no longer the airship last semester)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Since this course is all about self-learning, I’d like to give myself an A after all these sufferings I’ve gone through.
First it was the sh*tty HKMOOC online courses. The video there just does nothing to help you to answer the questions there, nor does it help you with the actual project. Basically, I learnt nothing out of those online courses.
And then there comes the nightmare. I didn’t know what to do with the project at all, but I don’t want to be a freerider, so I just opted to do the app that would be used to control the car. AND IT WAS EXTREMELY DIFFICULT since I had no programming background whatsoever. Luckily, there is a god-level groupmate that knows how to write an arduino program so I could just do everything else on the app inventor without the need to mess with those horrific arduino codes (though I still spent quite a few weekends to finish the app).

HKMOOC 20%

App & motor demo 5%
Drawings 5%
Team Portfolio 20%

Here is the mark allocation but it’s pretty much useless since you know nothing about your scores.
Just for your reference, out team was 3rd in the final competition (out of a total of 12 groups) and I got a really satisfying A+ in the end.
reviews.comment_workload:
Just like what the other comment mention, it’s either luck or one man army.
I was lucky enough to have 3 AWESOME groupmates that made our project sooooooo much better. There is an ISD student (which basically translates to professional mainland student who already knows everything), a guy from Robomaster who was able to take care of all the 3D printing jobs (forgot to mention just now but you have to include a 3D printed part in your final design), and someone who is willing to do the woodwork and go out to buy extra materials (and then there’s me writing my app). (Lets not talk about that freerider in our group since I’m in a good mood today)
Given such amazing groupmates, we still had to spend some extra days in the lab before the first build demo and the final competition, so I would say that this course’s workload is pretty high.
(Not really related, but another guy in our class had 4 f**king freeriders in his group and he had to do everything by himself. Yet he still managed to win the competition. So if you are a genius like him, a one-man-army wouldn’t really be your concern.)
Side note: taking ELEC1100 beforehand would help quite a bit on this course (especially when you’re an engineering newbie like me) since it taught about the electronics stuff which you would need for your online course and actual project, and some basic arduino code writing, which would also be really helpful when you’re writing the app.

reviews.author: Endrave
reviews.title: Either Luck or one man army
reviews.comment_content:
In my view the course isn't only teach you how to build a airship, learn how to write app with app inventor and arduino code,design drawing, 3D print . More like let you know how to running a project and work and lead the team to work.  

Here you are learning how to make your airship to be a product ready to be sell. so you will have to present your airship,do some demo test and the will be a competition at the end of the course.

All you need is ask Google. (sometimes instructors help too)
reviews.comment_grading:

IF YOU FINISH ALL THE JOBS (like me), you get an A+

reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is extremely light.
Just spend a few hours (10+) to google the answer of online materials and you will get almost 95% correct.
Just spend a few days to google on how to write C programmes and use MIT app inventor then you can finish all the quiz.
Just practice a few weeks on how to make 3D models,  do laser cutting and do welding then you can finish the car in 2 weeks before the final tasks. Then you will have extra time to revise other important Course.
